awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Computational and Data Intensive Astrophysics at the University of Florida
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for starting a new REU Site at the University of Florida with a focus on computationally intensive research in astronomy and astrophysics. The new program will take advantage of cutting-edge supercomputing available at the University of Florida as well as the newly established Informatics Institute. In addition to working in areas of astronomy, students will develop computer skills that will prepare them for a wide range of careers. The program will recruit students nationally, but will place particular focus on regional students with otherwise limited research opportunities.

The research projects available to students include cosmological simulations of the growth of galaxies and their properties, simulations and analysis of cosmological microwave background observations using next generation ground-based experiments, and simulations of future space-based gravitational wave data and analysis. Students will be trained in the development and use of supercomputing codes and facilities with a focus on astrophysics. The skill set is transferable to a number of careers both in and outside of the STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded a set of student participants from around the country to participate in cutting-edge research with faculty and postdoctoral scholars within the University of Florida astrophysics department.  The program successfully ran from the Summers of 2020-2022, inclusive, and was in an online-only modality for the first two years owing to the pandemic.

 

In sum total, we worked with 29 undergraduate students, which resulted in peer reviewed papers, one American Astronomical Society Chambliss undergraduate research award, two Chambliss honorable mentions, and at least 3 studenst being admitted to PhD programs.  These 29 students were admitted out of a total applicant pool of 296 competitive applications.   Our program succeeded in attracting historically underrepresented minorities, with 35% of our final cohort identifying as people of color, and 55% of our final cohort identifying as either Female or non-binary.

We conducted pre-and post REU surveys in order to identify areas of success in our program.  By and large, students self-reported strong improvement in scientific computing skills, as well as scientific communication skills.  The latter is likely the outcome of weekly seminars that we ran working on student communication.  

The students in our program worked on a diverse range of topics, from computational galaxy formation to idenitfying extrasolar planets, to advanced data science and machine learning applications to large datasets.  Alongside the technical skills that the students acquired in their projects, students also participated in weekly seminars to develop soft skills, including communication, scientific writing, graduate school application tips, and methods for reading scientific literature efficiently.
